This award strives to conserve biodiversity and manage natural resources in ways that maintain their long-term viability and preserve their potential to meet the needs of present and future generations. Activities include combating illegal and corrupt exploitation of natural resources and the control of invasive species. This includes Peru’s location makes it a hotspot for wildlife trafficking of many species listed in CITES as threatened with extinction or vulnerable to future extinction. USFWS has supported the proponent in responding to the Peruvian government’s requests for assistance to combat wildlife traffic domestically and along its borders. Achievements include: National Strategy to Combat Wildlife Trafficking, and securing important international commitments on illegal wildlife trade in border areas (Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador). However, implementing these commitments and enabling responsible agencies to improve enforcement controls to combat wildlife trafficking is a challenge. Law enforcement must focus on controlling wildlife trade at exit points which is challenging due the difficulty of distinguishing illegal and legal trade of certain species and identifying laundered specimens that enter the legal trade chain through forged or fraudulent documents. This project will significantly reduce wildlife trafficking to conserve the Yellow-spotted Amazon river turtle (Podocnemis unifilis, CITES Appendix I) as a real-life pilot to address gaps related to trade and control of species, limited interagency coordination and unclear procedures in granting legal permits to manage and export CITES species, and Peruvian citizens’ limited information and awareness of the legal and illegal wildlife pet trade.. he purpose of this project is to support biodiversity conservation efforts in Peru through counter-trafficking measures with a focus on river turtles destined for international and domestic markets. We propose working alongside the Peruvian government to improve regulatory frameworks and increase interagency cooperation and response capacity. Through collaboration with public and private organizations, this project intends to distribute information on trafficking and the illegal pet trade to Peruvian citizens under the framework of the existing “if you buy, you are an accomplice” communications campaign..

description.narrative: U.S. assistance builds the capacity of Peruvian institutions to combat transnational organized crime more effectively, improve citizen security and social inclusion, sustainably manage Peru's diverse and fragile environment, and expand the benefits of Peru's economic progress to more of its citizens. Peru is one of the world's largest cocaine producers, a major money laundering center, a principal source of illegally logged timber and illegally mined gold, and the largest source of counterfeit U.S. currency worldwide. While economic growth has slowed for the past two years due to a slump in international commodity prices and the failure to implement second generation reforms, successive Peruvian governments have pursued judicious, market-based economic policies yielding over a decade of economic growth averaging five percent, which has halved poverty rates, reduced infant mortality, increased lifespans, and expanded access to education. Peru is one of the United States' most steadfast democratic partners in the region, and the continuation of bi-lateral assistance advances U.S. national security and economic interests.
